p: The International Agency for Research on Cancer has listed 19 substances with sufficient evidence for lung carcinogenicity in humans (Group 1) [ 1 2]. Many occupations and industries in Indonesia involve a variety of carcinogenic materials, such as asbestos and silica in construction and renovation work, welding fumes in steel processing industries, and diesel exhaust for truck drivers and operators of machine engines [ 2 3]. Epidemiological studies have reported the increased risk of lung cancer development in several occupations [ 4 5 6]. According to the global estimates of occupational accidents and work-related illnesses reported in 2017, about 21.1% of the tracheal, bronchial, and lung cancer deaths among men were attributable to workplace hazardous substances including dust, vapors, and fumes [ 7].
